gate.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the part of a fence or outside wall that you can open and close so that you can enter or leave a place
gate.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: We went through the gate into the orchard.
the wrought-iron gates of the palace
I left the engine running and ran back to close the gate.
Make sure that the back gate is locked, please.
The children poured out of the school gates.
gate.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the place where you leave an airport building to get on a plane
gate.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Air France flight 76 leaves from gate 6A.
gate.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the number of people who go in to see a sports event, especially a football match
gate.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: the amount of money that these people pay
gate.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: He heard Jack open the gate.
She locked the gate behind her.
They went through the gate into the orchard.
Someone left the gate open, and the dog got out.
She stood outside the front gate of the cottage.
Derek met us at the entrance gate.
Soldiers were guarding the main gate.
Ellie ran down the path towards the garden gate.
I carefully shut the farm gate behind me.
Lots of parents were waiting outside the school gate.
Their way was barred by huge wrought-iron gates.
gate.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to prevent a student from leaving a school as a punishment for behaving badly
gate.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: used after the name of a place, person, or thing to give a name to an event involving dishonest behaviour by a politician or other public official
gate.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Irangate  (=when members of the US government sold weapons to Iran in exchange for the return of American hostages)
gate.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: the door leading to the planes at an airport
gate.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Air France flight 76 will leave from gate 6A.
gate.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: the number of people attending a public place or event such as a football match, amusement park, film etc, or the total sum of money that these people pay
gate.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: Revenue for the television rights and gate receipts will exceed $10 million.
Universal Studios Hollywood concedes itstotal gate is slightly lower this year.
gate.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: if a company or organization opens its gates, it opens for business for the first time. If it closes its gates, it is no longer in business
gate.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: By the time Disneyland opened its gates, the city of Anaheim had increased to four times its size.
Falling orders forced the factory to close its gates.
